A CLEAR SET OF RULES: INCOMPLETE

T/ony first gives Peter an extremely vague spectrum of which actions are acceptable and which aren’t, and later on gives Peter and order that, in the way it was presented, was anathema to what he believes, without explaining his reasoning. The rules, in T/ony’s mind, seem to be there, but the only clear direction he gives Peter is to stay away from the weapons dealing.

In the car ride to Peter’s home, T/ony tells Peter, “don’t do anything I would do, and don’t do anything I wouldn’t do.” While the audience might find that joke funny, Peter would only know T/ony from what he’s seen on the media, and that with parental guidance, since he was eight at the most tumultuous, speaking from a PR perspective, part of T/ony’s life. While some of us might hear that line and go, “that’s the best advice you could give a child”, and we are the target of that line, Peter doesn’t know T/ony. He only knows him as I/ron Man and, maybe, as a genius engineer. Those directions are worthless to him further than the implied “use your common sense.” Just so we’re clear, I’m not saying T/ony doesn’t have that1, just that he’s telling Peter to react in an appropriate manner to the situation without direction as to what an appropriate reaction would be.

Then comes Peter’s first fight with the Vulture, T/ony’s second talk with Peter in the movie, and he tells him to stay out of it. He doesn’t say he’ll look into it, he doesn’t tell him to go to the authorities. He tells him not to look into the weapons dealing and, if he does come across it again, to call Happy. Like I said before, if T/ony was reading/listening to Peter’s messages, he probably had access to his and Happy’s communications, so he knew Happy was lowing Peter off. Maybe he thought that was alright because he was getting the messages and he’d know if there was trouble, but Peter didn’t know that. As I mentioned before, Peter doesn’t feel like T/ony’s reliable, so he didn’t trust T/ony had his best interests at heart or at least he didn’t think he knew what those were.

Furthermore, when he tried to argue against the rule, T/ony broke out the “Because I said so!” Which is the fallacy of appeal to authority. A lot of parents use it, which is why a lot of fans love the exchange and, I’ll bet, why the scriptwriters included it, but it’s worthless as a logical argument and sure to make most teenagers hurry to do the exact opposite of what you said, nevermind a teenager who already thinks you’re wrong, that you’ve failed him and sees you as an obstacle to his goals, even as he sees you as the path to them.

However, I feel like I have to point out that, at least, T/ony doesn’t create the rules thinking about himself, but about Peter. He was honestly trying to protect him.2 I think he should get credit for that.

[1: Although I certainly think so. 2: He’s just inept.]



RESPECT: FAIL

T/ony consistently looks down on Peter. To be fair, most of the times he does this he’s trying to make a joke, but his humor is, not only with Peter but with most people, condescending and disrespectful.

In CA:CW, while he compliments him on his powers and inventions, he does it as a power move. Maybe not intentionally, but cornering a teenager in his own room and one by one throwing all of his most dangerous secrets right in his face like you do it every Tuesday, even as the teenager in question gets progressively more agitated, only served to build himself up and put Peter in the spot. Personally, I don’t think that when T/ony mentions May he’s implying he’ll tell her about Spider-Man, but there’s no doubt that Peter is feeling like Damocles’ sword was giving him a very close shave. He was at a disadvantage, even if T/ony wouldn’t press, even Peter didn’t think T/ony would press.

From Peter’s video, we know that he didn’t see or talk with T/ony at least until they gathered at the airport. T/ony told him what to do, gave him a tip on how to do it, convinced him not to listen to what Cap said1 and sent him off. No explanation given, he gave information on a need to know basis and didn’t think Peter even needed to know the real reason why they were fighting.

In the middle of all that, though, I missed a step. He gave Peter the suit. At that particular moment, all that suit had going for itself were the new webshooters (they may look nicer, but we are given no reason to believe they are, with the training wheels protocol in place, any better than the original), the (maybe) improved lenses and being more stylish1. Meta textually, all it served was to give Spider-Man his suit2. In the movie, all the purpose it could have served was, if we’re being generous, T/ony wanting Peter to have something nice3 or not wanting to be seen badly for bringing someone in rags and, if we’re not, T/ony paying for a service.4

In the car ride, he makes the joke about May.5 A woman isn’t relevant only in relation to the men in her life and a man is supposed to understand that he doesn’t control the women in his life and that they are not a comment on himself. That said, T/ony was locker room talking Peter’s mom. He not only passed him off to Happy, he told him that someone, not him, would call him if they needed him. That was the last Peter heard of him for two months.

Then comes the fight with the Vulture. That’s the first time Peter hears anything about his suit having a parachute, a tracer or a heater. After explaining the whole story to T/ony, he says they can take the Vulture down and T/ony replies with “taking him down now, huh? Crocket, there are people who handle this sort of things.” He condescendingly tells Peter that he’ll be out of the case and when Peter asks if he’ll be the one who’ll handle it, he says it’s too unimportant. That’s when he reveals he isn’t there with Peter but seemingly on vacation in India. From this point on, Peter stops trusting T/ony cares about him personally. The “Because I said so!” line makes an obligatory appearance in this section, because he hasn’t given Peter a good reason not to go after the Vulture. We can guess from his outburst that he’s worried about him, but Peter can only hear his words and they’re telling not to do his job because he says so, and then he goes on to belittle his efforts in CW. He has plenty of reasons to believe T/ony sees him as nothing but the kid he picked up and unfortunately got stuck to his hand. He goes on to tell Peter to stay with the small stuff and be “friendly neighborhood Spider-Man”.6

He bribes him with easy entrance to MIT7 and leaves instead of using that convenient moment to bring up the other things the suit can do, since he won’t be accessing to it until he’s completed the training T/ony was apparently supposed to give him, and he hasn’t even started yet, so it’s not important, right?

Except Peter accesses to it and, if he wasn’t annoyed by T/ony by then, the “Training Wheels” and the “Baby Monitor” protocol would have finished the job. The first one, admittedly, isn’t that bad in its name and not bad at all in its purpose, but it existed in the context of all the other ways T/ony made Peter feel inadequate and like a kid. The Baby Monitor, on the other hand, was downright patronizing in its name and a breach of privacy that outdid the tracer in the suit.

Then, out of nowhere, T/ony calls him to congratulate him (pointing out Peter’s lie and ignoring the fact he clearly doesn’t want to talk to him, but then again, he probably programmed the AI to connect his calls directly, so he never much cared about that) and inserts himself in the role of a father to this kid he’s talked to four times (this is a manipulation from Marvel). At every point he disregards Peter’s wishes, going so far as to tell him not to cut him off when Peter says he’s in the middle of something. That call wasn’t about Peter, it was about himself.

The mission goes sideways until T/ony gets there and saves everyone. I’m hesitant to include the “I think you’ve done enough” line since Peter did mess up and its delivery wasn’t condescending so much as angry.

During their talk post-ferry, the talk is peppered with “stereotypical parental lecture” catchphrases, which is what fans want to see, I assume, is why no one bothers to notice how inappropriate it is for someone whose interactions with a kid can’t amount to more than a day all put together to insert himself as a father figure in his life and then start with methods such as constantly making reference to his authority as an adult instead of making actual arguments. “I’m fifteen” may not have been the most devastating of all smackdowns, but “This is where you zip it! The adults are talking” is an immediate and absolute shut down of communication, because, even if the other person rebels against it and keeps talking, the “adult” already expressed unwillingness to listen. And I’ve talked about how he puts Peter in his debt with his comment about others thinking he was crazy for recruiting a “14” year old (see how the age gap and so his superiority just grows), but here he also makes it as though Peter was at fault for that for being young, while also telling him how no one else believes in him, while also implying he doesn’t believe in him anymore.8

Then he takes the suit away. I think that was the right choice. I mean, personally, I don’t see how it was that much better than his own suit beyond looking better and being better for the acrobatics he’s known for9 until he hacks it, but he’s not supposed to access to all the suit’s capabilities anyway (again, something I agree with). It’s just a toy, but one that enabled him to go against T/ony’s orders and taking it away is the best way to punish him (if it was apart from the “nothing” issue) and keep him from repeating is actions. There’s not much to criticize about his choice to take the suit away  (again, except for the conversation which gave that choice context) except maybe that, because that suit was the only thing that tied the two of them together, taking it away was basically giving up on the relationship, but I’ve already explained that the relationship was based on Peter admiring T/ony and what he represented, reaching out and lashing out when he perceived rejection and T/ony ignoring Peter, so it’s not much of a loss. There’s especially nothing to criticize in regards of T/ony disrespecting Peter.

Nothing, that is, except the clothes. It isn’t only humiliating and, if the writers had a bit of common sense, a sign for May that something bad happened10, it’s also petty and vindictive in a way that casts a bad light on the good parts of his lecture, which are already few, because they don’t seem to come from the right place, one of genuine intent to do right by Peter, but out of desire to take out his anger on him.11

Their next interaction is when Peter “has proven himself to T/ony” and gets invited to the upstate facility. Without the slightest hesitation, a thought spared to whether Peter harbored any resentment for the way he was treated (even if T/ony doesn’t think he’s done anything wrong, he has to know, because sometimes that’s what he was going for, that he upset Peter, as all people get upset when they’re lectured and punished), T/ony throws an arm over Peter’s shoulders welcomes him back and takes credit for motivating Peter, even though he went against T/ony’s wishes, after a talk in which he was torn down for not doing as he said. He paid so little mind to Peter himself that he planned the rest of his life in advance for him, starting12 right then, as soon as he suited up, with dozens of reporters waiting to drill the fifteen year old whose only exposure to attention greater than that of his class when he answered a teacher’s question was at AcaDec. Then Peter rejects him and he lets him go, after a quick “look at me (I’m the best thing that could ever happen to you). Still no? Okay, I’ll take this in a dignified way since you’re so adorable. I mean, look at it! It’s so smart, it’s almost like it understands what you’re saying!” That may seem like I’m being mean-spirited, but with the billionaire saying he digs the “working-class hero vibe”?13 It’s not.

I repeat, most of T/ony’s moments of condescendence are either jokes or T/ony’s/RDJ’s way of carrying himself that might make mostly innocuous comments offensive or probably his way of lashing out when he’s angry or upset. It’s not planned or out of maliciousness, just thoughtlessness. If it wasn’t, he probably would have told Peter that it wasn’t a test when he asked14, to manipulate him, maybe guilt him into agreeing. That doesn’t change their effect.

FAIR FEEDBACK: INCOMPLETE

On my count, T/ony shows Peter a reaction to his actions five times. Of those, two of them are exaggerated and one is complicated, as I will explain shortly.

The first two, will be analyzed together due to their similarity1, are in CA:CW, in the bedroom scene, and in the car scene in Homecoming. Although, as I’ve explained, there are problems with the context of that praise, it’s honest and an appropriate response when you think someone’s skilled. A simple “this is good work”, just like in the car scene. That time, he’s technically talking to May about Peter’s (fictitious) work at the retreat, but I don’t think it’s a stretch to say it’s meant for Peter.

The third feedback moment, the complicated one, is the phone call right before the ferry accident. I say it’s complicated because, in the context of everything else we’ve seen before in the movie, that was out of character and mostly for plot convenience. Despite that, what we get to hear shows it would have been “fair feedback”, at least given what T/ony knows, and possibly a turning point for their relationship that might have led to a good mentorship, if it hadn’t come at that particular moment. He calls after hearing about him saving his friends at Washington and mentions “great things to come, which we can assume means the training which would have led to more frequent2 interaction and communication which would probably have solved most of the problems I’ve pointed out. However, from an objective point of view, that feedback wasn’t fair, since the Washington incident was Peter’s fault. He was the one who brought the Chitauri energy core and left it with his non-powered friend after just picking it off the streets and irresponsibly not telling the police or anyone who could deal with it better than him (except T/ony) and carrying it around on him. Those actions deserved punishment. He also used it to disobey T/ony’s orders and investigate the Vulture’s operations. If he had had this information, T/ony most likely wouldn’t have congratulated him. Peter, by not giving him all the information, prevented him from performing his duties as a mentor correctly, but this happened because T/ony failed to provide him with a sense of reliability and alienating him by not respecting him. This leaves us, for the purposes of this section, with a situation in which T/ony doesn’t actually give Peter fair feedback, but it isn’t completely his fault.

The fourth time is the post-ferry lecture. In this case, he was right to choose to punish Peter, but wrong in the delivery of that punishment. I’ve explained everything that bothers me about this scene: T/ony is condescending in how he says things; his chastisement is based around Peter not listening to him instead of the things he actually did wrong and led to him endangering people, among which are being too eager to please him and his whole involvement with the Chitauri energy core, which didn’t actually affect the outcome of the ferry accident; his whole lecture does more harm than good. Then, by taking away the suit, he ends the relationship with Peter. That’s his reaction to, to his knowledge, Peter’s first strike. Instead of trying to fix things, he just discards him. Maybe he planned to give it back, but that would make the threat intentionally manipulative, which would be even worse.

The fifth time is at the upstate facility where, after Peter did everything he told him not to, again, which he punished him for before, he praises him3 and offers to make him an Avenger4. Peter does what he was punished for doing before, which includes endangering people the same way he did at the ferry (he showed up to fight crime, things went sideways and he tried to fix it. The only difference is that he needed help in the ferry while both the plane and the beach were miraculously empty), only he succeeds this time, and T/ony’s reaction is to give him everything he wants. I’m not saying Peter doesn’t deserve reward, I’m saying that T/ony’s is over the top, not only because he doesn’t deserve it, but also because it would end up being bad for him. The Avengers are the Big Leagues and he’s not ready for it.5 Even if they took the time to train him, he’d have to upend his life as Peter Parker, even if he didn’t reveal his identity.6 He’d have to drop out, and tell his Aunt at the very least, since her life would be upended, too. He’s not getting what he thinks he’s buying since the Avengers at that point are not the idealized elite who saved him and all the world when he was eight, but just T/ony, Vision and a disabled and probably still recovering Rhodey, who are bound by the Accords and now completely beholden to the UN. If you’re doing Peter Parker right, he’ll never agree to only acting when he’s allowed, or doing something he thinks is wrong. They got this right in the movie by making him go against T/ony even though he’s his hero. If it’s true that T/ony told people that he recruited a teenager and they were judgmental, he’ll be exposed to that skepticism.7 He’ll be (immediately) exposed to the media’s scrutiny as the new Avenger, and the one that came after Civil War.

What I’m trying to say with all this is that once again T/ony’s reaction is over-the-top and inappropriate. He also gives Peter the wrong message: succeed and I’ll give you the world; fail and I’ll take it away. There is also the small uncomfortable matter that, while this may not have held weight in his decision, Peter’s success was closely tied with doing T/ony a favor by saving his plane. It wasn’t the point, but it goes to show that constantly trying to make everything about T/ony has its downsides.

[1:and because all I have to say about each of them is “you didn’t fuck up here” and that’s hardly paragraph worthy. 2: As if that was hard, they were at rock bottom at “never”. 3: And claims credit for Peter’s success stop claiming credit for Peter’s success ffs. 4: As the Avengers stand at that point. 5: I’ve said it once and I’ll say it again, he’s plain incompetent. 6: Spider-Man would be the best hero to use to show the effects of the Accords, since he’d be screwed over without prep or lube by them, but Marvel didn’t intend to take that anywhere, which shows even in Civil War, since most of the movie and for most of the characters it isn’t about them anyway. 7: And he won’t be able to prove them wrong.]



AID: COMPROMISED / DISTANCE: FAIL

So, you thought I’d be nice to the relationship/T/ony St/ark.

As I said before, T/ony provides a lot of aid. He takes care that the suit “suits” Peter1: it has the lenses to prevent overwhelming his senses, the new webshooters, it fits his acrobatic lifestyle better2, it has tracers he can use knowingly and apparently some other functions which activate automatically in case of emergency if Peter can’t do it himself.3

Furthermore, it has some kind of devise to warn him if Peter’s in some trouble the suit can detect (although it does depend on Internet connection) and, when he gets that warning, T/ony wastes no time to get a suit to save him, just as he goes running when he figures out Peter’s on the ferry, where he knows a deal’s about to go through. Then, he offers Peter a home at the facility, a place on the Avengers, the Iron Spider suit and a father figure in himself.4

All in all, when Peter’s on T/ony’s good graces, he holds the world upon a string.5 He’s provided with aid in spades. When it comes to actions of aid, I can’t complain at all. The only times when he didn’t come to Peter’s rescue in the movie were when it would make sense because he wasn’t keeping tabs anymore and the movie actually required his absence. It’s the material aid that, perhaps unfairly, I’ll admit, I’m not happy with. The problem is that he doesn’t manage well the distance I talked about in the introduction.

In every other way, he’s too distant. This distance means that his attempts at material aid backfire, because he’s not there to ensure the correct use of the equipment. Therefore, Peter first endangers himself by using the suit’s extra abilities because he doesn’t understand them and later uses them to go against T/ony’s wishes. In addition to give Peter this space to reject him, his distance also causes it by breeding resentment or/and disconnect on Peter’s side.

On the other hand, the moments and ways in which he’s present he’s overbearing. Physically and emotionally, he goes from ignoring Peter to taking the opportunity of saving him to set down rules that go against what Peter believes in and which, because of that, will be difficult to follow since the trouble he’s supposed to avoid is happening right before his eyes. Then he calls before the ferry incident, sets himself up as Peter’s father figure (by referencing his own father and saying he’ll succeed where he failed) and is about to tell Peter that he’s going to start training him. Note that I say “tell that” and not some other, more unassertive words like “suggest” or “offer”. It’s for a reason. In the call, T/ony constantly wrestles for control of the conversation, and from Peter. Without a by-your leave, he decides he’s going to try to parent Peter. That’s the basis of all their interactions, T/ony trying to move Peter to where he wants him, Peter resisting and T/ony dragging him or leaning on him to make him comply, with oftentimes poor results.

Other way in which he’s not giving room for Peter to be himself is by giving him the suit as it was. Remember when I mentioned that I’d use the comics to support my claims? Here it is. Putting aside the fact that Peter himself made the suit (the movie is apparently based on Ultimate Spider-Man6, and they already changed it so it would be Mary Jane who made him the suit instead there), a good example for what I’m saying is the spider-tracers. The original, 616 Peter Parker very early on made the spider tracers, simple spider-shaped devices that allowed him to track people, first with a receiver and later he programs them so he can find them with his spider-sense.7 You might remember a spider-like tracer in the movie. T/ony gave it to him and both it and the “receiver” are a hundred times more advanced than the ones Peter uses in the comics. Thus, he has no reason to keep working on it and will probably never figure out how to tap into his spider-sense’s frequency. The webshooters come with hundreds of different combinations programmed into them, so he has no reason to tinker with them. He has no reason to develop his skills at all because it’s all been handed to him. And it’s not like Peter wants to be a poet; he has both talent and interest in science but no reason to work on it. T/ony himself commented that his work was impressive. He said Peter in general, his skills, his powers, his morals, was great, but then the first thing he did was limit him and then try to shape him into something that fit him better, like someone who’d ignore trouble, someone who he saw as eventually going to want to use an Instant Kill Mode.

I’ve talked about the how, but here’s why the mentorship fails. T/ony is, at once, too distant and too overbearing.

He sees potential in Peter and so he invests in him with the suit, and takes measures to protect that investment by putting everything he thinks will help him survive in it. This means he has a very set path he wants Peter to follow and to that end put bumpers on the sides. Peter could get rid of them and do his own thing, but they make life easier and so he doesn’t even need to learn how to aim because he has the bumpers to fall back on. The moment Peter decides to try it anyway, T/ony shows no hesitation in cutting him loose and taking his investment back, though. And why wouldn’t he, if T/ony doesn’t tell him the rules of the game and won’t even play with him?

No, I don’t think T/ony does it on purpose. I think he does care about Peter. But if he’s a dad, he’s one of those rich ones who don’t make time for their kids and try to make up for it by buying them expensive gifts that they may or may not want and justify it by saying they’re just making sure they have a good future, even though their kids don’t want to work on their law firm.

[1: As I said before, it’s weird, and by weird I mean eye-rollingly-convenient, just how well T/ony could predict the needs of someone he hadn’t even met. 2: Toight. 3: Which is useful since Peter doesn’t know about them. 4: Don’t get up in my face, I never said T/ony didn’t care about Peter or might be open to a father/son relationship with him, only that he sucks at it. 5: I’ve already talked about what happens when he isn’t, but mentioning that in the main body is just being petty at this point. 6: In ways they wouldn’t like to admit. 7: Some people take a page out of Bruce Wayne’s book a prefix part of their name to everything to cope and that’s valid.]


CONCLUSION

If the father/son relationship between Peter and T/ony doesn’t exist. The scriptwriters used certain cues that are widely associated with parents reacting to their kids or blatantly compared T/ony to his father in how he acted towards Peter, implying he was filling the same role. Their interactions, though, are minimal and most plain conflictive, while almost all had problematic undertones and context, even when the characters had the best intentions. T/ony fails to communicate with Peter and so he fails him in almost every aspect, and by the time he gets his act together, Peter, while still admiring him and wanting his attention and to be an Avenger, has rejected his authority both because he doesn’t trust it and because accepting it would mean going against his own beliefs and wishes. Since Peter meets with failure, T/ony can’t tolerate the challenge and doesn’t see any reason to compromise and so cuts Peter off, claiming that it will be permanent. After Peter succeeds, T/ony welcomes him back without any of them addressing the issues that had set them apart before and tries to impose his way again by giving him everything he wanted, but Peter rejects him. They go their own ways, understanding that Peter will be his own person, and with this understanding also setting the groundwork for a better, functional relationship.

Fans, as it is their right, created a very different relationship following the cues and the emotional manipulation used in the movie. Marvel profits from it without having had to actually put effort into the relationship.

It should be pointed out that any mentorship relationship involving a teenage hero will always be problematic since the mentor will be complicit at best and completely to blame at most for child endangerment. Marvel realized this 60 years ago and, if my memory serves, until modern times no teenage hero has had a mentor or operated in a team, with team-ups being the exception, since Johnny Storm (and the rest of the FF family). This trend was started and popularized by Spider-Man.

Now, to the actual thing.

[[MORE]]

An ideal mentor should provide the mentee with: training (in whatever form this training takes, i.e. it counts if it’s just advice on life), support (the emotional kind), aid (more substantial support; equipment and actions fall into this category), a clear set of rules, respect (not that of an equal in the field the mentorship’s taking place, but at least that of a person to another, enough to see the mentee for what they are), fair feedback (appropriate encouragement when they do something right, appropriate punishment when they do something wrong), frequent if not constant assessment. This last one is especially important to make sure all these other things are being done adequately (it would be useless to try to teach a 5th grader math genius how to add, unfair to tell them that they can’t sleep over at a friend’s house because you’re afraid they’ll get home sick and want to go home when they’ve been doing it for a while now) and to give the mentee a sense of reliability, since a relationship has to be maintained by two people, and a mentee that doesn’t trust their mentor won’t let them perform their duties.

Most importantly, though, the mentor has to give all of this to the mentee as tools to use for themselves, understanding that eventually they should outgrow the need for mentoring. (Which doesn’t mean outgrowing the need/desire for the relationship itself. More in the sense of graduating and going from a friendly relationship with a teacher to becoming actual friends who respect each other as equals and aren’t part of an imbalanced relationship the way that of a mentor/mentee is.) This requires a very exact distance which allows the mentor to carry out their duties and receive feedback while still letting the mentee be their own person and grow on their own.

T/ony fails to provide everything but aid. I considered including fair feedback, but even that misses the “fair” part.



SENSE OF RELIABILITY: FAIL

T/ony doesn’t communicate with Peter, leading him to think he can’t rely on him.

There are ways to refute this statement, such as pointing out the suit, which T/ony made to protect Peter and into which he seemed to have put a lot of effort, or that he was listening to Peter’s messages, since he was able to mention the churro lady. I’ll address this later on. Right now, I’ll only say that what’s important isn’t being reliable1, but giving Peter a sense of reliability, which he failed to do, and so he disobeyed him at every turn. We can assume that Peter stopped giving Happy updates, so he stopped putting effort in the relationship, and when T/ony went to confront him when he messed up, Peter refused to acknowledge any kind of authority on his part except right of ownership of the suit. It could be said that this was because Peter was trying to prove himself worthy of becoming an Avenger and it was just childish rebellion and, while I wouldn’t disagree, I’d say that, be that as it may, Peter still rejected and circumvented T/ony’s authority. He was convinced he was wrong and tried to prove it by doing things on his own.2

[1: Which T/ony wasn’t, anyway. 2: As he’d been doing all along.]



TRAINING: FAIL

T/ony doesn’t train Peter. He doesn’t meet Peter until he’s had his powers for 6 months, probably has been Spider-Man for around 5, and has established himself as a “cool” (enough to have more than one video on YouTube1) vigilante, if not a hero in his own right. He goes to Germany and holds his own against both Sam and Bucky, even with all his fanboying2. He saved Rhodey from crashing into a plane. He was essential in beating Scott. 3 4

By the time CA:CW rolls around, ability wise, Peter has a handle on things5 that, while not perfect, can improve only with experience, which also goes for his ability to assess and react to a situation accordingly, and seems to have a grip on the direction of his career (go on patrol, help the “little guy”). He could handle himself in his chosen path and was no push-over when taken out of his element. Which is a good thing, since the only “training” he gave him, besides indoctrination to keep him from listening to Cap, was “aim for the legs”.

In Homecoming, for most of the movie Peter uses the St/ark suit. The only two features we see him use are: the new webshooters and the tracing chip (the one he uses himself). We can assume that, as far as Peter knows until his first fight with the Vulture, that’s all it does. Then, T/ony tells him that he put everything into his suit. Peter doesn’t really look into it, even after he finds out there’s a tracer in his suit. He hacks into it to take the tracer out and Ned tells him about the training wheels. More on some of this stuff later. What’s important now is that Peter wasn’t trained in how to use the suit. He wasn’t even told he was supposed to be trained. He didn’t know about the suit’s capabilities and, until he takes a moment to see for himself how it works, i.e. train himself, again, it actually hinders him.

SUPPORT: FAIL

T/ony and Peter talk all of six times during the movie, and that’s being extremely generous, since I’m counting the ferry call, the ferry save, and the post ferry scene as three different occasions. I’ll talk about each of them in other sections of the post, but at no point does T/ony ever provide emotional support to Peter. Him apparently reading/listening to his messages but not replying is him not providing emotional support. Actually…

Here it gets heavily T/ony critical. In the post-ferry scene, however you want to frame it, went horribly. Now, don’t get me wrong. Peter deserved a lecture. More. He, if you’ll forgive the parlance in the “objective” part of the post, fucked up. I’m not saying he didn’t. However, the way T/ony went about it was so wrong he provided the exact opposite of emotional support and drove him to tears hours after the fact AND to stop being Spider-Man. I know there will be those that will say, “Hey, that’s good, right? I mean, first you complain about him condoning his vigilantism and then you complain about him ending it? Make up your mind.” There’s a difference between making a minor understand that they shouldn’t do some things for their own safety and making them feel like screw-ups who are nothing without a piece of clothing.

Because here’s how the scene went. Peter screwed the pooch. T/ony informs him of this. Gives him a bit of a tongue-lashing. Peter asks if everyone’s okay. T/ony says no thanks to him. Not how I would have worded it, but I have both the disadvantage of closeness, because I know what Peter was thinking and I empathize with him because of that1, and the advantage of distance, because I haven’t landed on a roof after having to save all those people in the ferry along with the kid whose life I feel responsible for, after he disobeyed my orders. Peter gives voice to my thoughts: he was trying to protect people2, you know, his job. He points out that he had tried to tell T/ony, that he had asked for his help/him to play interference before, but he blew him off.3 He says that if T/ony cared, he’d be there.4

Then5, T/ony steps out of the suit. He tells him that he’d called the FBI. The FBI would have been –was—useless against the Vulture. Even if they weren’t, Peter didn’t know that, because the only thing T/ony told him was that the weapons dealing was too small for the Avengers6, but too big for Peter and to call Happy if he saw them again. Happy, who had been ignoring Peter like he was a street vendor. And if he knew enough about their communications to know about the churro lady, he had to know Happy was ignoring him. Actually, I want to quote him. “Take him down now, huh? Crockett, there are people who handle this son of thing.” He told Spider-Man to ignore his responsibilities.

T/ony, there’s no other way to say this, guilt-trips him by saying he was the only one who believed in him7. He says he got criticized for choosing to have faith in a 14yo. The only good reason to say that would have been to make Peter feel like he was in his debt. Then, after making the, ultimately, but only partially8, true assertion that if anyone had died that night it would have been on Peter (I want you to take a second to consider the callousness of telling a 15yo that; change the phrasing from “on you” to “it’s your fault”), he tells Peter that if he had died, he’d have felt responsible and that he doesn’t need that9. He’s making someone who already feels bad feel worse. That’s not the point of lectures. The point of lectures is making someone understand what they did wrong, why what they did was wrong, how to avoid it in the future and, maybe, how to fix it. Admittedly10, T/ony does that, but he completely tears Peter down in the process. I’m not saying that he should be allowed to get away scott free, either by T/ony or by the narrative, but that’s not the way to do it, because of many reasons, but mainly because Peter gets the wrong lesson. This is, first, because T/ony insists on making everything about himself. He blames everything that happened on Peter disobeying him; when Peter points out the way he failed, he makes an argument that, yes, saves him from looking like a complete ass, but fails to address the underlying root of the problem which is that Peter was reacting to the information he had available, which included absolutely nothing from him except (the illusion of) disregard; he makes himself the victim of the danger Peter gets into.

The last part draws into the second thing Peter got wrong about the lecture, which is that he’s a screw-up. He now not only feels guilty about his own failure, the whole blame for the accident has been laid on him11. Then, the coup de grâce.

T/ony asks for the suit back. (This is not it). Peter begs him not to, and then claims he’s nothing without the suit12.

And T/ony answers that, if he’s nothing without the suit, then he shouldn’t have it13.

And then he takes the suit.

…

Put it this way. Peter says A. T/ony answers “If A, then B” (A=>B)14. Then T/ony says B.

I know it’s not what he meant. I don’t think that’s what Feige, or Goldstein and Daley intended. Believe me, I do. That doesn’t change the fact that T/ony indirectly tells Peter he’s nothing, and Peter thinks he’s nothing, and the movie supports this by making the emotional climax of the movie about Peter proving he’s not nothing.

That is not emotional support. If it was done often enough, you could make a case for it being emotional abuse, especially since it was done at a time when Peter, a child who admires T/ony and so is very impressionable where he’s concerned, was already feeling guilty, so that T/ony’s words reinforce the thought that he’s nothing. And all of this is in the context of T/ony ignoring Peter for two months, appearing to ignore his worries, going back to ignoring him until he messes up, making the point of the following lecture that everything wrong that had happened on the ferry happened because Peter didn’t obey T/ony’s orders and then, the next time they speak, framing all of that and telling Peter, essentially, that he’s nothing, as a “the tough-love moment that he needed.”

I believe that the only reason a lot of people (I haven’t even seen anyone in the anti-T/ony crowd point this out) let this slide is because the moment follows T/ony’s oh-so-convenient call to Peter and instantly followed itself by his “Now I sound like my father” line, where he sets himself up in a fatherly role. A CLEAR SET OF RULES: INCOMPLETE

T/ony first gives Peter an extremely vague spectrum of which actions are acceptable and which aren’t, and later on gives Peter and order that, in the way it was presented, was anathema to what he believes, without explaining his reasoning. The rules, in T/ony’s mind, seem to be there, but the only clear direction he gives Peter is to stay away from the weapons dealing.

In the car ride to Peter’s home, T/ony tells Peter, “don’t do anything I would do, and don’t do anything I wouldn’t do.” While the audience might find that joke funny, Peter would only know T/ony from what he’s seen on the media, and that with parental guidance, since he was eight at the most tumultuous, speaking from a PR perspective, part of T/ony’s life. While some of us might hear that line and go, “that’s the best advice you could give a child”, and we are the target of that line, Peter doesn’t know T/ony. He only knows him as I/ron Man and, maybe, as a genius engineer. Those directions are worthless to him further than the implied “use your common sense.” Just so we’re clear, I’m not saying T/ony doesn’t have that1, just that he’s telling Peter to react in an appropriate manner to the situation without direction as to what an appropriate reaction would be.

Then comes Peter’s first fight with the Vulture, T/ony’s second talk with Peter in the movie, and he tells him to stay out of it. He doesn’t say he’ll look into it, he doesn’t tell him to go to the authorities. He tells him not to look into the weapons dealing and, if he does come across it again, to call Happy. Like I said before, if T/ony was reading/listening to Peter’s messages, he probably had access to his and Happy’s communications, so he knew Happy was lowing Peter off. Maybe he thought that was alright because he was getting the messages and he’d know if there was trouble, but Peter didn’t know that. As I mentioned before, Peter doesn’t feel like T/ony’s reliable, so he didn’t trust T/ony had his best interests at heart or at least he didn’t think he knew what those were.

Furthermore, when he tried to argue against the rule, T/ony broke out the “Because I said so!” Which is the fallacy of appeal to authority. A lot of parents use it, which is why a lot of fans love the exchange and, I’ll bet, why the scriptwriters included it, but it’s worthless as a logical argument and sure to make most teenagers hurry to do the exact opposite of what you said, nevermind a teenager who already thinks you’re wrong, that you’ve failed him and sees you as an obstacle to his goals, even as he sees you as the path to them.

However, I feel like I have to point out that, at least, T/ony doesn’t create the rules thinking about himself, but about Peter. He was honestly trying to protect him.2 I think he should get credit for that.

[1: Although I certainly think so. 2: He’s just inept.]



RESPECT: FAIL

T/ony consistently looks down on Peter. To be fair, most of the times he does this he’s trying to make a joke, but his humor is, not only with Peter but with most people, condescending and disrespectful.

In CA:CW, while he compliments him on his powers and inventions, he does it as a power move. Maybe not intentionally, but cornering a teenager in his own room and one by one throwing all of his most dangerous secrets right in his face like you do it every Tuesday, even as the teenager in question gets progressively more agitated, only served to build himself up and put Peter in the spot. Personally, I don’t think that when T/ony mentions May he’s implying he’ll tell her about Spider-Man, but there’s no doubt that Peter is feeling like Damocles’ sword was giving him a very close shave. He was at a disadvantage, even if T/ony wouldn’t press, even Peter didn’t think T/ony would press.

From Peter’s video, we know that he didn’t see or talk with T/ony at least until they gathered at the airport. T/ony told him what to do, gave him a tip on how to do it, convinced him not to listen to what Cap said1 and sent him off. No explanation given, he gave information on a need to know basis and didn’t think Peter even needed to know the real reason why they were fighting.

In the middle of all that, though, I missed a step. He gave Peter the suit. At that particular moment, all that suit had going for itself were the new webshooters (they may look nicer, but we are given no reason to believe they are, with the training wheels protocol in place, any better than the original), the (maybe) improved lenses and being more stylish1. Meta textually, all it served was to give Spider-Man his suit2. In the movie, all the purpose it could have served was, if we’re being generous, T/ony wanting Peter to have something nice3 or not wanting to be seen badly for bringing someone in rags and, if we’re not, T/ony paying for a service.4

In the car ride, he makes the joke about May.5 A woman isn’t relevant only in relation to the men in her life and a man is supposed to understand that he doesn’t control the women in his life and that they are not a comment on himself. That said, T/ony was locker room talking Peter’s mom. He not only passed him off to Happy, he told him that someone, not him, would call him if they needed him. That was the last Peter heard of him for two months.

Then comes the fight with the Vulture. That’s the first time Peter hears anything about his suit having a parachute, a tracer or a heater. After explaining the whole story to T/ony, he says they can take the Vulture down and T/ony replies with “taking him down now, huh? Crocket, there are people who handle this sort of things.” He condescendingly tells Peter that he’ll be out of the case and when Peter asks if he’ll be the one who’ll handle it, he says it’s too unimportant. That’s when he reveals he isn’t there with Peter but seemingly on vacation in India. From this point on, Peter stops trusting T/ony cares about him personally. The “Because I said so!” line makes an obligatory appearance in this section, because he hasn’t given Peter a good reason not to go after the Vulture. We can guess from his outburst that he’s worried about him, but Peter can only hear his words and they’re telling not to do his job because he says so, and then he goes on to belittle his efforts in CW. He has plenty of reasons to believe T/ony sees him as nothing but the kid he picked up and unfortunately got stuck to his hand. He goes on to tell Peter to stay with the small stuff and be “friendly neighborhood Spider-Man”.6

He bribes him with easy entrance to MIT7 and leaves instead of using that convenient moment to bring up the other things the suit can do, since he won’t be accessing to it until he’s completed the training T/ony was apparently supposed to give him, and he hasn’t even started yet, so it’s not important, right?

Except Peter accesses to it and, if he wasn’t annoyed by T/ony by then, the “Training Wheels” and the “Baby Monitor” protocol would have finished the job. The first one, admittedly, isn’t that bad in its name and not bad at all in its purpose, but it existed in the context of all the other ways T/ony made Peter feel inadequate and like a kid. The Baby Monitor, on the other hand, was downright patronizing in its name and a breach of privacy that outdid the tracer in the suit.

Then, out of nowhere, T/ony calls him to congratulate him (pointing out Peter’s lie and ignoring the fact he clearly doesn’t want to talk to him, but then again, he probably programmed the AI to connect his calls directly, so he never much cared about that) and inserts himself in the role of a father to this kid he’s talked to four times (this is a manipulation from Marvel). At every point he disregards Peter’s wishes, going so far as to tell him not to cut him off when Peter says he’s in the middle of something. That call wasn’t about Peter, it was about himself.

The mission goes sideways until T/ony gets there and saves everyone. I’m hesitant to include the “I think you’ve done enough” line since Peter did mess up and its delivery wasn’t condescending so much as angry.

During their talk post-ferry, the talk is peppered with “stereotypical parental lecture” catchphrases, which is what fans want to see, I assume, is why no one bothers to notice how inappropriate it is for someone whose interactions with a kid can’t amount to more than a day all put together to insert himself as a father figure in his life and then start with methods such as constantly making reference to his authority as an adult instead of making actual arguments. “I’m fifteen” may not have been the most devastating of all smackdowns, but “This is where you zip it! The adults are talking” is an immediate and absolute shut down of communication, because, even if the other person rebels against it and keeps talking, the “adult” already expressed unwillingness to listen. And I’ve talked about how he puts Peter in his debt with his comment about others thinking he was crazy for recruiting a “14” year old (see how the age gap and so his superiority just grows), but here he also makes it as though Peter was at fault for that for being young, while also telling him how no one else believes in him, while also implying he doesn’t believe in him anymore.8

Then he takes the suit away. I think that was the right choice. I mean, personally, I don’t see how it was that much better than his own suit beyond looking better and being better for the acrobatics he’s known for9 until he hacks it, but he’s not supposed to access to all the suit’s capabilities anyway (again, something I agree with). It’s just a toy, but one that enabled him to go against T/ony’s orders and taking it away is the best way to punish him (if it was apart from the “nothing” issue) and keep him from repeating is actions. There’s not much to criticize about his choice to take the suit away  (again, except for the conversation which gave that choice context) except maybe that, because that suit was the only thing that tied the two of them together, taking it away was basically giving up on the relationship, but I’ve already explained that the relationship was based on Peter admiring T/ony and what he represented, reaching out and lashing out when he perceived rejection and T/ony ignoring Peter, so it’s not much of a loss. There’s especially nothing to criticize in regards of T/ony disrespecting Peter.

Nothing, that is, except the clothes. It isn’t only humiliating and, if the writers had a bit of common sense, a sign for May that something bad happened10, it’s also petty and vindictive in a way that casts a bad light on the good parts of his lecture, which are already few, because they don’t seem to come from the right place, one of genuine intent to do right by Peter, but out of desire to take out his anger on him.11

Their next interaction is when Peter “has proven himself to T/ony” and gets invited to the upstate facility. Without the slightest hesitation, a thought spared to whether Peter harbored any resentment for the way he was treated (even if T/ony doesn’t think he’s done anything wrong, he has to know, because sometimes that’s what he was going for, that he upset Peter, as all people get upset when they’re lectured and punished), T/ony throws an arm over Peter’s shoulders welcomes him back and takes credit for motivating Peter, even though he went against T/ony’s wishes, after a talk in which he was torn down for not doing as he said. He paid so little mind to Peter himself that he planned the rest of his life in advance for him, starting12 right then, as soon as he suited up, with dozens of reporters waiting to drill the fifteen year old whose only exposure to attention greater than that of his class when he answered a teacher’s question was at AcaDec. Then Peter rejects him and he lets him go, after a quick “look at me (I’m the best thing that could ever happen to you). Still no? Okay, I’ll take this in a dignified way since you’re so adorable. I mean, look at it! It’s so smart, it’s almost like it understands what you’re saying!” That may seem like I’m being mean-spirited, but with the billionaire saying he digs the “working-class hero vibe”?13 It’s not.

I repeat, most of T/ony’s moments of condescendence are either jokes or T/ony’s/RDJ’s way of carrying himself that might make mostly innocuous comments offensive or probably his way of lashing out when he’s angry or upset. It’s not planned or out of maliciousness, just thoughtlessness. If it wasn’t, he probably would have told Peter that it wasn’t a test when he asked14, to manipulate him, maybe guilt him into agreeing. That doesn’t change their effect.

FAIR FEEDBACK: INCOMPLETE

On my count, T/ony shows Peter a reaction to his actions five times. Of those, two of them are exaggerated and one is complicated, as I will explain shortly.

The first two, will be analyzed together due to their similarity1, are in CA:CW, in the bedroom scene, and in the car scene in Homecoming. Although, as I’ve explained, there are problems with the context of that praise, it’s honest and an appropriate response when you think someone’s skilled. A simple “this is good work”, just like in the car scene. That time, he’s technically talking to May about Peter’s (fictitious) work at the retreat, but I don’t think it’s a stretch to say it’s meant for Peter.

The third feedback moment, the complicated one, is the phone call right before the ferry accident. I say it’s complicated because, in the context of everything else we’ve seen before in the movie, that was out of character and mostly for plot convenience. Despite that, what we get to hear shows it would have been “fair feedback”, at least given what T/ony knows, and possibly a turning point for their relationship that might have led to a good mentorship, if it hadn’t come at that particular moment. He calls after hearing about him saving his friends at Washington and mentions “great things to come, which we can assume means the training which would have led to more frequent2 interaction and communication which would probably have solved most of the problems I’ve pointed out. However, from an objective point of view, that feedback wasn’t fair, since the Washington incident was Peter’s fault. He was the one who brought the Chitauri energy core and left it with his non-powered friend after just picking it off the streets and irresponsibly not telling the police or anyone who could deal with it better than him (except T/ony) and carrying it around on him. Those actions deserved punishment. He also used it to disobey T/ony’s orders and investigate the Vulture’s operations. If he had had this information, T/ony most likely wouldn’t have congratulated him. Peter, by not giving him all the information, prevented him from performing his duties as a mentor correctly, but this happened because T/ony failed to provide him with a sense of reliability and alienating him by not respecting him. This leaves us, for the purposes of this section, with a situation in which T/ony doesn’t actually give Peter fair feedback, but it isn’t completely his fault.

The fourth time is the post-ferry lecture. In this case, he was right to choose to punish Peter, but wrong in the delivery of that punishment. I’ve explained everything that bothers me about this scene: T/ony is condescending in how he says things; his chastisement is based around Peter not listening to him instead of the things he actually did wrong and led to him endangering people, among which are being too eager to please him and his whole involvement with the Chitauri energy core, which didn’t actually affect the outcome of the ferry accident; his whole lecture does more harm than good. Then, by taking away the suit, he ends the relationship with Peter. That’s his reaction to, to his knowledge, Peter’s first strike. Instead of trying to fix things, he just discards him. Maybe he planned to give it back, but that would make the threat intentionally manipulative, which would be even worse.

The fifth time is at the upstate facility where, after Peter did everything he told him not to, again, which he punished him for before, he praises him3 and offers to make him an Avenger4. Peter does what he was punished for doing before, which includes endangering people the same way he did at the ferry (he showed up to fight crime, things went sideways and he tried to fix it. The only difference is that he needed help in the ferry while both the plane and the beach were miraculously empty), only he succeeds this time, and T/ony’s reaction is to give him everything he wants. I’m not saying Peter doesn’t deserve reward, I’m saying that T/ony’s is over the top, not only because he doesn’t deserve it, but also because it would end up being bad for him. The Avengers are the Big Leagues and he’s not ready for it.5 Even if they took the time to train him, he’d have to upend his life as Peter Parker, even if he didn’t reveal his identity.6 He’d have to drop out, and tell his Aunt at the very least, since her life would be upended, too. He’s not getting what he thinks he’s buying since the Avengers at that point are not the idealized elite who saved him and all the world when he was eight, but just T/ony, Vision and a disabled and probably still recovering Rhodey, who are bound by the Accords and now completely beholden to the UN. If you’re doing Peter Parker right, he’ll never agree to only acting when he’s allowed, or doing something he thinks is wrong. They got this right in the movie by making him go against T/ony even though he’s his hero. If it’s true that T/ony told people that he recruited a teenager and they were judgmental, he’ll be exposed to that skepticism.7 He’ll be (immediately) exposed to the media’s scrutiny as the new Avenger, and the one that came after Civil War.

What I’m trying to say with all this is that once again T/ony’s reaction is over-the-top and inappropriate. He also gives Peter the wrong message: succeed and I’ll give you the world; fail and I’ll take it away. There is also the small uncomfortable matter that, while this may not have held weight in his decision, Peter’s success was closely tied with doing T/ony a favor by saving his plane. It wasn’t the point, but it goes to show that constantly trying to make everything about T/ony has its downsides.
